text:
Hi there! I am stuck with a perf comparison with C code which is almost twice as fast as my julia version (I gain 10% if call julia with fastmath mode, but it still is far from C). Of course I can use threads easily, but that is kind of not the point. Any obvious improvement from the following julia code?
```using BenchmarkTools

cx(x, side, scale) = x / side * 2 * scale - scale
cy(y...) = cx(y...) * 1im

function solvePixel(i, i_n, side, center, scale)
    y, x = divrem(i, side)
    c = cx(x, side, scale) + cy(y, side, scale) + center
    z = 0im
    k = 0
    while (k < i_n)
        z = z * z + c
        abs(z) <= 2 ? k += 1 : break 
    end
    return 1 - k / i_n
end

function res_(idx, i_n, side, center, scale)
    return UInt8(floor(solvePixel(idx, i_n, side, center, scale) * 255))
end

function main(; i_n=512, side=2048, center=0.4 + 0.4im, scale=0.3)
    open("out.ppm", "w") do io
        write(io, "P6 $side $side 255 ")
        buffer = Matrix{UInt8}(undef, side, side * 3)
        for i in 0:side - 1
            tmp = i * side
            for j in 1:side
                idx = tmp + j
                res = res_(idx, i_n, side, center, scale)
                @inbounds buffer[i + 1,j * 3 - 2:j * 3] .= res
            end
        end                     
        write(io, buffer)       
    end
end

@benchmark main()```

elements.text: Hi there! I am stuck with a perf comparison with C code which is almost twice as fast as my julia version (I gain 10% if call julia with fastmath mode, but it still is far from C). Of course I can use threads easily, but that is kind of not the point. Any obvious improvement from the following julia code?

using BenchmarkTools

cx(x, side, scale) = x / side * 2 * scale - scale
cy(y...) = cx(y...) * 1im

function solvePixel(i, i_n, side, center, scale)
    y, x = divrem(i, side)
    c = cx(x, side, scale) + cy(y, side, scale) + center
    z = 0im
    k = 0
    while (k < i_n)
        z = z * z + c
        abs(z) <= 2 ? k += 1 : break 
    end
    return 1 - k / i_n
end

function res_(idx, i_n, side, center, scale)
    return UInt8(floor(solvePixel(idx, i_n, side, center, scale) * 255))
end

function main(; i_n=512, side=2048, center=0.4 + 0.4im, scale=0.3)
    open("out.ppm", "w") do io
        write(io, "P6 $side $side 255 ")
        buffer = Matrix{UInt8}(undef, side, side * 3)
        for i in 0:side - 1
            tmp = i * side
            for j in 1:side
                idx = tmp + j
                res = res_(idx, i_n, side, center, scale)
                @inbounds buffer[i + 1,j * 3 - 2:j * 3] .= res
            end
        end                     
        write(io, buffer)       
    end
end

@benchmark main()

text: Does much change if you replace `abs(z) <= 2 ? k += 1 : break` with `abs2(z) <= 4 ? k += 1 : break`

elements.text: Does much change if you replace
abs(z) <= 2 ? k += 1 : break
with
abs2(z) <= 4 ? k += 1 : break

text: The other obvious performance gain is to do your calculations in terms of x and y instead of `i` and `j`. This would remove a bunch of divisions, which are probably the other slow part of this.

elements.text: The other obvious performance gain is to do your calculations in terms of x and y instead of
i
and
j
. This would remove a bunch of divisions, which are probably the other slow part of this.

text:
Oh my, just using `abs2`  was enough to beat the C program by 5-10% (which is also doing something similar in the end).
As I am improving an existing code, and I never used `im` in Julia I was not expecting something like this.
Thanks <@U0179G7FG4F>

elements.text: Oh my, just using
abs2

was enough to beat the C program by 5-10% (which is also doing something similar in the end).
As I am improving an existing code, and I never used
im

in Julia I was not expecting something like this.
Thanks

text: glad that worked. `abs` for complex numbers is a bit of a performance trap because it really looks like it should be fast, but is about 20x slower than `abs2` since it has to do a complex square root

abs2
since it has to do a complex square root

text: It makes sense mathematically, just I didn't even think about it

For the sake of showing numbers:
C with -Ofast
```jeff@jeff-jfli:~/Tests$ time ./mandelfast

real    0m2,278s
user    0m2,202s
sys     0m0,020s```
